This Company's system of submarine telegraph

South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: CAIRO AGRICUTLURAL SHOW
div.p: Tomorrow the biggest agricnltural show ever beld in Egypt will be inangorated at Cairo. The exhibition will be open from 8 p.m. ontil 6 p.m. to-morrow and from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on the lst, 2nd, 8rd, and 4th March. A military band will be in attendance.

A short preliminary description of the show may not be oat of place. The bnilding iteelf is fi led with an excellent collection of cottons of the various Moadiriehs, as well as grain. Vegetab'es are found in a separate kiorqne. The Society have many more animals than their shed really acoommod tes, and this year they have cattle, which they bave pot had for many years. Horses, moles. donkeys, camels, and sheep are found. A featare of the show is the representetion of native in- dustries, wocdwork, etc. Natives will be at work at their respective craf'e, and 800 me. tres of +beddi g will be occupied by these indastries. Technical echools are also exhi- biting. Machinery, ploughing tackle, as well as engines, pumpr, mills, etc, are *huwn.

div.head: LECTURE ON WAGNER
div.p: A very ifnt@erting lectare opon Wagner and his wogid'Was given on Monday afternoon by apts W.S Gairdner at Counanght Hone, siro, to a very appreciative andience. Mr. Gairdner devoted bis attention to Wagner as a mosician rather than a dramatist, showing very snccinctly the great diff -rence of bis works prodeced before 1830 and those of bis latter life, nrodoced after a lJapse of three or foor years, which period be devoyed to stody and to developing bis ideas. thon bh .w the-e earlier work, ') be F ying Datchman," "Tann- hauser," and 'Lobevgrn," were characterized by melodies pearly always metrical in character, rbythmical in constraction, aod clearly governed by the words to which they were set; while his later works were of ar entirely d ff-rent character—free melodies with no soggestion of metre nor words, with bat little regolarity of form, illostrative of abstract thoughts or characters rather than words, aod almost invariably interpreted by the orchestra rather than the voice, which was mostly cor fined toa running recitative. Mr. Gairiper very clearly illustrated the metrical tendency of this early period, showing from exsmples taken fiom ''l'anubauser' that the lyrics grouped them-elves almost jnvefiably into quatrain form, which arrangement was almost av obcession cf be day aid which often resvl'ed in mun>otopy if not in actual weekpes of compostion, ths masic being dominated by the words with more or less conventional cadanves. 'l'bis form of lyric was the conventional one of the day; and M- Gairdner showed hw Hadyo, M zart, and otbers broke away from this stersotyped idea by their improvisation on the fragments of osrtain metrical themes. 'T'his he exemplifi-d by the stream of free melody in Mossrt's j ibilee symphony, and aleo by Beethoven's sym phony.in C. minor, of which the first foar chords boid ap nearly the whole movement Thongh there are certain traces of this use of free melody in some of Wagner's early works they were bat experimentnl;and it was nodoabt owing to bis years of stedy and realizstion of his tbeorie: that his later work are so char- rather than theory.

I: ig evident that Mr. Gairdners knowledze of the wot ject is extensive envagh to give bim materials for more lectnres thau the ore we li-teped to wih much pleasure oo Monday. Wagner' mosi is au exbsostive su! jest ; and it Mr. G i dner can ouly be persaadei to give farther illusrations and explanations which will make it easier of comprehension 'o the limited anderstanding bis remarks will be reeeived with becoming gratitude by many.

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB CAIRO
div.p: The first Bachelors' Sapper held at the British Recreation Clob, Cairo, on Satarday evening last, was a credit alike to the promo- ters, the bachelore, and the caterers' manager, and Mrs.Holmes. All the tickets were rapidly bought op, and the tastefully decorated sup- per hall and fi,wer bedecked tables, fally oceapied as they were by guests, presented a most pictare-que and animated spectacle. The menu (ali Bogli-h) was discussed ino very practical mauner after which a toast list end masical programme was submitted, aod carried throogh with rare spirit. The chair man, Mr. Aitcbesou—or as he is bet'er and more populary known at the clab as Artcheson 'Bey"—gave of bis best, bis sparkling sallies fsirly convalsing the assemb'ed o mpany at times. His learned dissertation on Egyptology was a thing to be remembered, his apparent in timate knowledge of the history of the Tombs of the Sacred Balle somewhat stagger- ing his not too exsctjng atdidece He pro- posed the toast of 'Phe Clab," Mr. I-on that of the "Marriei Members," to which latter Mr. Soow replied. Messrs. Walton, 'Treasure, Watt, Haye:,Saew, Heywood, Ison, Stevenson, Kimmer, and Band Sergeant Geogebegan, contributed to the masical programme. Mr. Sammere, accompanying in his asaal accepta- ble manner, in addition to rendering sondry pisnuforte solos with taste and feeling. Votes of thanks t» the chairman ; to Mr. Sommers ; to the manager and Mrs. Holmes ; and to all who had onntribated to the success of the and 'Gi S.ve the Kiog," brooght a» bighy sucves+fal and harmonious evening toa close

div.head: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY
MEETING TO-MORROW
div.p: The meating of the members of the General Assembly of the Legislative Conncil takes p'ace to-morrow. In virtne of the constitational law of the Egyptian Government, this Assembly meets every two years. The three last ocos sions on which it met were March 8, 19/2, F sbroary 22, 1904, and April 3, 1905 The lat'or was an extraordinary meeting convoked bv Khedivial deoree as the Government had to acbmit to the General Assembly a decree relative to the measdres to be taken to figh: the cotten "Worm. Although this year the government lias no project of great importance tc communicate to the Arsembly, the meeting wil take place to-morrow in conformity with the organic decree. It will be held with the mcustomed ceremony at the Ministry of Piblic Works. The Khedive will open the sitting and deliver the customary speech

"The Gsneral Assembly is simply the Lagis lative Comncil over again, with the addition of the six ministers and of forty six members popularly elected. This Assembly bas no legis- lative fanetione, thoogh it is entitled to pass resolotions on any subject of public interest— resolations which 'he Government is tree to teke as moch or as little notice of as it pleaser. [t has, however, one most important power of a negative kind, inasmach as no new taxes e:n be imposed withont its consent. This is» provision which might evidertly some day or other enable the Assembly to play a vary onsiderable part in Egyptian pol ties. But, sitce 1888, the Government has been in the tortanate positioa of pot requiring to inipose pew taxes apon its native sabjeots, except the tax necessary to facilitate the alolitioa ot the corvée, which, for reasons already explained, the Assembly made no d fhi- ct lty aboat accepting. That bedy, therefore, his not been sammoned oftener than four pative qoestion in Africa seems liable to be| times since its oreation (the organic decree overlooked. 'be possibility of large groaps of tribes, hitherto distinct and matoally antago- vistic, becoming rapidly able and esger to anderstand each other in some common form of speech, has apparently to be taken into account. Twenty-six years' contact with Swahili and various dialects of Esstern and Central Africa points so far to the conclusion that there is a remarkable degree of sithilarity, amounting in many important respects to substantial ident- | ity, in the grammatical stractore of language over the whole vast area occupied by the races of Africa, from the Sudan to the Cape. _ The ffi iale, missionaries, traders, settlers and travelers of various nationalities who are qualified to give belp in testing this conclasion by personal and first-hand stady «fa Banta dialect are naterally difficalt to reach, scatter- ed in remote and cften isolated spheres of work. It is, therefore, perhaps justifiable to ask publicity for the request, that persons #0 qualified and willing to accept and reply to a brief commanication on the sabject would rend me their addresses at Fort Jameson, North Bastern Rhodesia. I should be grateful if foreign journals and local papers in Africa, general avd Official, would assist by calling p:oviding that it mast meet at least once every to years), and ite discassions bave generally been brief and colooriess. As far as can be jodged, ita characteristics do not differ mate- rislly from those of the Legislative Council, though as the proportion of Government nomineer, who form the best element of bo*b bodier, is emaller in the Assemb'y than in the Coancil, the decisions of the former won!d be more likely to prove fantastic and anworkable than those of the latter."

2. On acconnt of the dependence of the a bool on the University of Al Ashar ard the opacity of the papils who have completed their ovurse to teach at the said university, the school will create a class of men "eapable of in spiring geveral confidence in their re'igious k :owledge and general ability.
3. The school will inclade two sections, the first of which will train very capable clerks and will serve as a preparatory school for the scond class.

div.head: THE STREET NUISANCES OF CAIRO
FROM A PEDESTRIAN'S POINT OF VIEW
div.p: To rue Editor or tHe "Egyptian Gazettes'

Sir,—I shonld like to make some remarks iv voor colamas oa the above subject, which ems of interest both te visitors and to those whose welfare is involved in maintaining the oopalarity of this city as a place of resort. Dividing these remarks onder sanitation, traffic, and mendicity,

Firstly —Why is it considered necessary to varge the various templesdedicated to C nacina st 10 o'elock on a Sanday morning, which also appears to be the day and hoor fixed for shaking carpets, etc, ont of apper windows? Furthermore, coald not the aathorities orn cerned arrange to cleanse the varions street refase-bins béfere these receptacles become aa abomination?

Secondly as to trafic. The Sharia Gainena has been "ap" ever since Ootober, asphalte is beiog laid down, and this sf cted street has in rotation presented to the public a sketchy impression of the Bernese Alps, a fair coarse for an obstacle race, and an spirited representation of the destraction of the Cities of the Plain. This street is also a kind of cyclonic centre for dranken brawls, the gentle fe tah treqnents an Armenian liqnor den jast off the main strest, qnarrela in his caps over the favoars of one or more of the attendant Hebee, and goes out into the street t fight it oat with moch beilowing and thrashing of the air with sticks. After the whole neighbourhood has been aroused a shawish comes ap and appeals to the principal villaiti as a man ania brother to go home. This attifude is dae to inadeqrate available force and not t» fank, for I bave seen an Ezyptian policeman make 4 mst dptorained arrest of an intoxicated Bey whose friends stragg ed desperately to eff wt a rescue while the crowd all sympathised or covertly impeded the arrest. However, the policeman kept his temper and his man, and withoat drawing his tranchaon evantaally marched his bey--hip off to the oaracol.

Before leaving tha police, it might be askad why they do not, whon issaing licenses to arbaghie, insist on some test of driving and topography. Tha local Jeha has no ides of eithar, aod having also no "haols," plies the whip savagsly and casselassly to cover his defects (printer p'esse note that thie is not a paradox). Accidente would be more treqaent if the horses were not anderfed | and the pace slow. He is however a sports- man in his way, and his chief recreation con- sists in endeavoaring to "ran down" wall- dressed Europeans. dast according to local atmos; heriowgndition®, or, if be bas a clear street before him and the khawagah does not look like a "sprinter," he , can slash bim over the face with his whip. It is a safe amusement, too, for most Earopeans | koow better than take the case op. A month ago an arbaghi came op behind me along the Sharia Kamel and with the whole road to epare hagged the right side and withoot a word of , warniog | felt his off horse's shoulder cannon | into mine ; he had plenty"of space bat having some experience in "riding off" I got olear of his boofs and the wheels, bat still it was not a bad attempt. Io that same street shortly after, a friend of mine—an E iglishmin—had mach the same experience. He pat ap his hands instinctively to ward off the impact, and the driver slashed at him viciously with his whip as he passed. Stang and indig»ant, my friend gave chase to get the man's uamber. The , vehicle tarned ap a side street and stopped. Finding no ommber on th@oarriags (it was after- | wards foand te belong to one of the hotels) ha | accosted the arbaghbi aod on the lat'er refosing to give any account of himself proceeded to arrest him. There was a scofiis and the Boglishman was dropped with a deftly-fling | stone on the temple. Being real grit he picked himself up, closad with his man, and he'd him till a policeman came ap, nor did be inflict any further violence on the man afcer appre- hending him. He, however, had no evidence , while the very horses were, believe, prepared to give testimooy on tha o-her side, also the policeman, whom my frisad hai omittei to win over. the arbaghi for assanit and fired £5 and £3 ee the able-bodied cripple—with or without oso- motive applianees—and worse, far worse than all, — the starving, maimed, aad soffering children with parente—or other adalts in that guise — watehing them from some point of vantage.

There is now on the streets of Cairo a tall, fine-looking fellah about thirty years of age, who leads by the hand an emaciated, filthy little girl, a mere child of five or so. She has hor feet tarned iow srds and her legs are too weak to sapport her body for aey distance. "he man come; toa oafé or open bar, gives thechild a paxh andin she staggers, falls on har kanes, with her contorted limbs doubled ander her, and whines shrilly. When she comes out the man takes what she has ia cash, throws aay food away that she may have reosived, and drags her along to the next likely resort. If the couple meet a respeoctably dressed pedestrian moving slowly along some more or less deserted street the same process is gone throagh with the same resalt. 1 have given the aofortuoat: child money, and food, as many others do, bat I determioed to watch the procesdiags, with the above resalt. The man I have often seea withoat his stock-in- trade, the centre of « large and garralous throng at one of the lower-class cafés and, apparently, at once the host and eatertainer of the party. Faugh!! It isenoogh to make a bysena sick to think of it.

Is there no remedy ! Is this inoflax of meodicants in the tourist season too great for the police to cope with or is no eff rt made t» keep sach people within the boands of ordinary deescy aod hemanity! I regret the length of this article, aor om I[ per- haps the best person to write on sach sahjscts, bat if | can thereby prevent the maltraatmenot and explvitatioa of one wretched ohild, I shall feel that it has no: boea written in vain. Tad travelling apper-classes, who form the mainstay of Cairo's wealth, and who pre- samably have sach delicacy and sympathy as a libaral edacatioa shoald give, are hardly likely to look with favoar oa a city where gach naaseoas, harrowiag, aad disgasting experiences are of daily oocsarrenca, and practically anavoidsble.—Yours feithfally, AppaLlan Manson.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: This morning's tel show that the gallantry of Prince Henry ot the Netherlands at the wreck of the Berlin has been warmly appreciated in Eagiand. The Prince married Q een Wilhelmina io 1901. He belongs to the Hoase of Mecklembarg-Schwerio and was born in 1876
we regret to learn that Princess Nazli Hinem Fadi hae soffered a relapse and her condition iospires some anxiéty.
Fathi Bev Zighloal, the new Under Secretary to the Muioistry of Jastice, visited that Ministry on Monday, accompanied by the Judicial Adviser.
The Jadicial Ads iser lefton Monday evening for atoar of inspection ia Lower Egypt, accompanied by Abderrabman Bey Rida.

Mr. Hobler, late of the British Agency, Cairo, is proceeding to Adis Abeba to take over the offi sial daties of Sir John Harring ton, Minister Plevipotentiaty and Consal General, during the latter's absénce from Abyssinia on lesve.
Hassein Pasha Moharrem, Obief A. D. C. to the Khedive, has not retired on pension, as repor'ei. It is his brother, Dr. Hagen Bey Moharrem, who has retired from his Highn ess's service
Mr. Wells, luspector of Miner, will leave Cairo shortly for Keneh and thence proceed to the Red Sea Coast, where he will inspect the mining concessions.

div.head:
IMPERIAL PARLIAMENT
DR. MCEKNNA'S BILL
RECOGNITION OF PRINCE'S BRAVERY

div.p: House or Commons.—Dr. McKenva's Bill was reai for the first time and adopted by 264 votes to 109. [t provides that denominations! sohool managers should refand to the locs| authorities one-fifteenth of the teachers' salaries, representing the cost of denominationa instraction, otherwise the school would cease to be recognised. Mr. Balfour did not oppose the measure.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman announced that the King bad conferred the Grand Cross of the Bath on Peince Henry of the Netherlands for | bravery in connection with the Berlin disaster. | He added that the House woald rejoice to see | the speedy recognition of his conspicaons gallantry and devotion. Sir B. Grey has te- legraphed to the British Minister at the Hague Great Britain's warm appreciation of the work of rescue carried out by Prince Henry and the lifeboatmen, whose names he reqvested to be forwarded with a view to their being suitably rewarded
(Feuter)

div.head:
THE GERMAN ELECTIONS
GOVERNMENT TACTICS CONDEMNED

div.p: Prince von Bu'ow, replying to attacks of the Centre on the Government's election tactics, described as inventions the allegation of the interference of the Crown. The Government claimed the right to enlighten electors and would dbe this right on s moch larger ecale in fatare elections.
( Reuter )

In the Reichstag, Herr Bebel stigmatiad the official candidatares. Prince von Bulow reproached the Socialists fof their anti-patriotic attitade and appesled to the anion of the midile classes to render the defeat of tle Socialists definitive.
(Havas)
Herr Dernburg will start on a four months tour in East Africa in May
(Fueter)
The Senate has passed the Bill relating to public meetings
(Havas)
A bolier explosion has occurred on H.M.S Dragon. Two men were killed and four injured.
(Feuter)

div.head: THE OASIS OF SIWA

div.p: Dr. T. C. Ewald Falls, the eminent German Ezyptologist, has sent the following to the "Frankfort Gazette," from which Se have trans lated :—

Most of the camelaserved for the transport of the nineteen tents, the 120 iron water tanks (containing Cairo wate), 200 water } gs, and the foraze. Even the natives who know the way through the maritime regions to the green island in the Libyan sand-ocean can be counted. The Mariout Bedonins have two caravan roads to | Siwa. div.head: ADMINISTRATION OF PORTS AND LIGHTS
NOTICE TO MARINERS
RED SEA-SANGANEB REEF
New Lighthouse
div.p: A lighthouse has been erected on the Sooth end of Sanganeb reef, near Sheik el Bargout (Port Sudan). and the light was exbi- bited permanently on February 15 b.
The position of the light from the sooth end if the reef, in nearly the same position as that of the old beacon.
Name of light—Sanganeb.
Po-ition—Asabove Lat. 19°43'N. Long 87° 26° E.
Nomber and Ooloar of light—One, white.
Character of light—Single fl shing.
Period of revolution, five seconde — i.e.Flash 4 sec. Obscurity 44 seco: de.
General description of bailding—Open framework tower.
Height of focal plane above H. W. 105 feet.
Height of buildirg above H. W. 180 feet.
Character of appsaratos or order—First order—Dioptric.
Colour of _ building—Chooolate—Men's rooms white and white lantern.
Miles seen in clear weather—20.
The temporaryfixed light has been abolished. i8 Dingcror Generac. Alexandria, February 26th 1907.

Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
